etymologies: mid 16th century (in an earlier sense). From post-classical Latin legativus (already in classical Latin as lēgātīvus in sense ‘relating to legacies’ (attested in an inscription (2nd century a.d.)); compare also classical Latin lēgātīvum payment made to ambassadors for expenses (2nd century a.d.)) from classical Latin lēgāt-, past participial stem of lēgāre + -īvus

definitions: Of or relating to a legate (especially a papal legate); legatine.
